title: 110_s1672
content: The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Education Assistance Program under Chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to provide financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility at accredited educational institutions in a State. The scholarship program established under the VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 aims to increase the number of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The Secretary will promote the program to educational institutions nationwide, with a focus on those with high numbers of Hispanic students and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. To participate, individuals must submit an application and agreement to the Secretary. To participate in the scholarship program, individuals must submit an application and agreement to the Secretary, agreeing to serve a period of obligated service in return for educational assistance. The Secretary will provide application and agreement forms with a summary of rights and liabilities, as well as terms and conditions for participation. Upon approval by the Secretary, individuals can join the program. Upon approval by the Secretary, individuals become participants in the scholarship program and receive financial assistance to cover tuition and fees. The amount of assistance is determined by the Secretary based on the individual's educational needs. The financial assistance provided under this chapter for education must not exceed the necessary tuition and fees for the required credit hours. The total assistance for a full-time student cannot exceed $15,000 per academic year. Assistance for part-time students is proportional to full-time students. The total financial assistance provided under this chapter cannot exceed $45,000 and the duration of assistance is limited to six years. An agreement between the Secretary and a participant must be in writing and include the Secretary's commitment to provide financial assistance as authorized. The participant must sign an agreement with the Secretary to receive financial assistance under this chapter. The agreement includes accepting the assistance, maintaining enrollment and attendance in a specified program of study, maintaining academic standing, and committing to serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after program completion. The agreement for educational assistance under this chapter requires the participant to serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after program completion. Repayment is required if the individual fails to meet the agreement terms, as determined by the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to establish repayment amounts and exceptions under section 8004. Regulations allow for waiver or suspension of obligations in cases of noncompliance due to uncontrollable circumstances. Any repayment obligation is considered a debt to the United States. An obligation to repay the Secretary under this section is considered a debt owed to the United States, not discharged in bankruptcy if within five years of the agreement termination. Clerical amendments are made to title 38. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code, within six months of the enactment of this Act.
